{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15383,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Platanthera grandiflora, also known as the Greater Purple Fringed Orchid, requires a consistently moist environment. It thrives in habitats with high humidity and needs ample water to maintain its lush appearance. When cultivated, it's important to simulate these conditions by watering the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently damp but not waterlogged. It's best to water early in the morning to allow for evaporation excess by night. Ensure that the plant is never left to dry out completely, as it can lead to stunted growth or wilting of the delicate flowers."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Platanthera grandiflora flourishes in environments with partial to full shade. In its natural habitat, it is accustomed to dappled sunlight under canopy cover. For indoor cultivation or in gardens, it should be placed in a location where it receives indirect sunlight for a few hours each day, ideally in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the intense heat of midday sun. Direct sunlight can be too harsh, potentially scorching the leaves or flowers, so it is essential to protect the plant from excessive direct exposure to ensure its health and vibrancy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Platanthera grandiflora is generally minimal. These orchids benefit from the removal of dead flower stems and any brown or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. This should be done carefully using sterilized pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease. It's best to prune after the blooming season to encourage fresh growth for the following year. Avoid cutting too late into the fall as this can disrupt the plant’s preparation for dormancy. Regular inspection and gentle cleaning encourage a robust blooming season in the next cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Greater Purple Fringed Orchid","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Greater Purple Fringed Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Platanthera grandiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14188,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cladonia macilenta, commonly known as the \"lipstick lichen,\" generally requires minimal watering as it primarily absorbs moisture from the air due to its lichen nature. In artificial growing conditions, it's important to keep the surrounding environment humid. Mist the lichen lightly if kept indoors to replicate its natural humid habitat. Avoid over-watering, as excess moisture can actually damage the lichen. The key is to maintain a balance, ensuring the lichen remains moistened by misty conditions rather than direct watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cladonia macilenta prefers bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate a range from partial to full sunlight conditions depending on its natural habitat. If cultivating indoors, place it near a window where it will receive ample diffused light throughout the day. Direct sunlight should be limited as it may lead to drying out, especially in hotter climates. Outdoor conditions should mirror natural exposure in woodlands or open areas where it commonly grows, under tree canopies that provide dappled light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cladonia macilenta is not typically necessary as this lichen does not follow traditional plant growth patterns. However, if you find yourself wanting to manage its growth or remove dead or discolored sections, you can gently trim with small scissors. It’s generally best to leave it be unless necessary, as interference might affect its natural development. When performing any trimming, ensure your tools are clean to prevent introducing contaminants to the lichen's surface. Monitor the lichen's health, but keep pruning to a minimum."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lipstick Powderhorn","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Lipstick Powderhorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Cladonia macilenta"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14783,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Parthenium hysterophorus, commonly known as Santa Maria feverfew or whitetop weed, is a hardy plant that can thrive in various environmental conditions. It requires minimal watering once established, as it is drought-resistant. Overwatering can lead to poor growth and increased susceptibility to diseases. To maintain optimal health, water the plant sparingly, ensuring that the soil is allowed to dry out between waterings. During prolonged dry periods, occasional irrigation can help sustain the plant, but in humid or wet climates, natural rainfall usually suffices to meet its water needs. "},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Parthenium hysterophorus thrives in full sunlight and is well-suited to environments with high sun exposure. Ensure the plant receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. In shaded or partially shaded areas, the plant may grow but won't exhibit its full potential and might not produce seeds as prolifically. It is tolerant of harsh, sunny conditions, making it adaptable to a variety of climates, including arid regions. Therefore, when cultivating Parthenium hysterophorus, situating the plant in a location that gets abundant sunlight is ideal for robust growth. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Parthenium hysterophorus is typically unnecessary in its natural settings, as it is a weed that spreads rapidly without intervention. However, if growing it in a controlled environment or garden, light pruning can help manage its size and spread. Pruning should be done carefully, using gloves, as the plant can cause allergic reactions. Focus on removing flowering and seeding parts to help control its propagation, as it tends to invade and dominate spaces quickly. Regular trimming can prevent it from becoming invasive by managing its growth and curbing excessive seed production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Santa Maria feverfew","description":"Parthenium hysterophorus is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. It is native to the American tropics. Common names include Santa-Maria, Santa Maria feverfew, whitetop weed, famine weed, and congress weed. In India, it is locally known as carrot grass, congress grass or Gajar Ghans. It is a common invasive species in India, Australia, and parts of Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Tropical America"],"other_name":["Santa Maria feverfew"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Parthenium hysterophorus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15079,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leptarrhena pyrolifolia, also known as Leatherleaf Saxifrage, prefers consistently moist soil. It thrives in environments that replicate its natural habitat, like the moist areas of alpine and subalpine meadows. It is crucial not to let the soil dry out completely, especially during its growing season in spring and early summer. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Regular watering is essential, but always check the topsoil to ensure it's not overly saturated before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leptarrhena pyrolifolia thrives best in partial to full shade conditions, as it naturally grows under the canopy of larger vegetation in alpine and subalpine environments. It can tolerate full sun but only if the soil is kept consistently moist; excessive sun exposure can lead to leaf scorch. In garden settings, it is ideal to plant it in shaded areas or areas that receive filtered sunlight throughout the day. If grown indoors, placing it near a north or east-facing window will mimic its natural light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leptarrhena pyrolifolia involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and encourage healthy growth. This should be done in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut back the foliage to the base of the plant, removing any browned or withered leaves. This will help in directing energy towards healthy leaf production. Additionally, spent flower stalks should be cut back post-bloom to neaten the plant’s appearance and possibly encourage new blooms in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"leatherleaf saxifrage","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["leatherleaf saxifrage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Leptarrhena pyrolifolia"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15182,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnosporangium clavipes, known as Cedar-quince Rust Fungus, does not require watering itself as it is a pathogenic fungus. However, managing the water conditions around host plants, like cedar and various rose family trees (such as apple or hawthorn), can impact fungal development. Avoid overwatering these host plants as excess moisture can facilitate the growth and spread of the fungus. Ensuring good air circulation and proper drainage around your plants helps reduce the humidity levels that encourage rust fungi development."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gymnosporangium clavipes itself doesn't benefit or suffer directly from sunlight, but host plants can. Ensuring host plants receive adequate sunlight is crucial in maintaining their health, which can indirectly help in managing the fungus. Good sunlight exposure can promote stronger, more vigorous growth in plants like apple or cedar, potentially reducing the susceptibility to infections. Thus, place these plants in locations where they receive plenty of sunlight, ideally around 6-8 hours daily."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential in controlling Gymnosporangium clavipes as it helps manage the fungus by removing infected parts of host plants. Regularly inspect your cedars and apples or hawthorn trees for galls or infected shoots, especially in early spring when symptoms may appear. Prune out and destroy infected plant materials to reduce the spread of the fungus. Always use clean, sharp tools and sterilize between cuts to prevent disease transmission within the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"quince rust","description":"Gymnosporangium clavipes is a plant pathogen, a fungus that causes cedar-quince rust. Similar to Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae and Gymnosporangium globosum, the fungus infects a wide range of Rosaceae, such as apple, hawthorn and quince trees, and also requires an evergreen host such as eastern red cedar or a number of other juniper species to complete its life cycle.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["quince rust"],"pest_susceptibility":["Rust fungi"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Gymnosporangium clavipes"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Reduce watering frequency during cooler months when the plant's growth rate decreases, allowing the topsoil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chiococca alba thrives in partial to full sunlight. In particularly hot or intense sun areas, it may appreciate some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorching and maintain vibrant foliage. This is typically done in late winter or early spring before the growing season begins. It is also beneficial to trim back any stems that are leggy or overgrown to encourage a dense and bushy growth habit. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts and prevent unnecessary stress on the plant. Regular pruning supports healthy blooming and can help control the size if the plant becomes too large for its space."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"West Indian milkberry","description":"Chiococca alba is a species of flowering plant in the coffee family, Rubiaceae native to Florida and the extreme southern tip of Texas in the United States, Bermuda, Mexico, Central America, the Caribbean, the Galápagos, and tropical South America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14279,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trillium luteum prefers consistent moisture, especially during its active growth period in spring. It's important to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. This plant is sensitive to drought, so ensure the soil does not dry out completely. However, during its dormancy in summer, you can reduce watering, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Always use well-drained soil to prevent root rot. Rainwater or distilled water is preferable as it mimics natural conditions and prevents mineral build-up. Observing the surrounding environment helps adjust watering frequency, especially if grown in woodland settings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trillium luteum thrives best in partial to full shade, mimicking the dappled sunlight conditions of its native deciduous woodland habitat. It doesn't tolerate direct sunlight well, particularly the harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch its leaves. An ideal location is under trees or in a shaded garden where it receives indirect light or morning sun. Providing shade during the hottest part of the day helps maintain the right temperature and humidity levels, ensuring healthy growth and flowering. If grown indoors or in shaded areas with very low light, artificial grow lights can be used to supplement natural lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Trillium luteum doesn't require extensive pruning. It's mostly about maintenance and cleaning up dead foliage. After flowering and once the leaves start to yellow naturally in late summer going into fall, you can gently remove any dead or damaged leaves by cutting them back to the base. This helps prevent disease and maintains a tidy appearance. Avoid cutting green foliage as these leaves store energy for next year’s growth. Be gentle when handling as disturbing the plant's roots can impact its flowering potential in subsequent years."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"yellow wakerobin","description":"Trillium luteum, the yellow trillium or yellow wakerobin, is a species of flowering plant in the bunchflower family Melanthiaceae with native populations in the Great Smoky Mountains of the United States and surrounding areas.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["yellow wakerobin"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Trillium luteum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14483,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gentiana andrewsii, commonly known as the closed bottle gentian, prefers consistently moist soil. It thrives in a garden setting with adequate moisture levels, so regular watering is crucial, especially during dry spells. Ensure the soil remains damp but not waterlogged, as overly saturated soil can lead to root rot. Providing a layer of mulch around the plant can help retain soil moisture and reduce evaporation, ensuring the roots stay cool and moist. During the plant's dormant season in winter, reduce watering but do not allow the soil to completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentiana andrewsii prefers partially shaded to full-sun conditions, depending on the climate. In cooler climates, it can tolerate full sun, which will often result in more robust flowering. However, in hotter regions, it's best to provide some afternoon shade to protect the plant from intense sunlight, which can scorch the leaves. Ideally, provide a spot with morning sun and afternoon shade. By balancing sunlight exposure and providing good lighting conditions, you can ensure healthy growth and vibrant blooms while minimizing stress on the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gentiana andrewsii is minimal and primarily focused on maintaining plant health and encouraging dense growth. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to promote better air circulation and prevent disease. In early spring, before the plant begins active growth, cut back any spent stems to the ground level to make room for new growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15574,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abies fraseri, commonly known as Fraser fir, requires moderate watering throughout its lifecycle. When young, ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Regular watering is crucial, especially during dry spells, to help the tree establish itself. As the tree matures, it becomes more drought-tolerant, though it still benefits from occasional deep watering during prolonged periods of dryness. A good approach is to water deeply once a week, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings, to encourage deep root growth. Using mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fraser fir thrives best in full sunlight to partial shade conditions. Ideally, the tree should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which supports robust growth and a dense, healthy foliage canopy. While the tree can tolerate partial shade, adequate sunlight is critical for preventing sparse foliage and weak growth. It's essential to plant Abies fraseri in a location where it doesn't compete with taller trees for sunlight. If grown indoors or in a garden with inconsistent light, supplement with grow lights to ensure the plant receives sufficient luminescence to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fraser firs should be done sparingly and primarily for shape and health. The best time to prune is early spring, just before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to improve air circulation and promote healthy growth. Avoid heavy pruning, as firs generally do not respond well to aggressive cutting. Lightly trim back overgrown branches to maintain a conical shape, characteristic of Fraser firs. Use sharp, clean tools to make precise cuts just above a healthy bud or side shoot. Annual inspections and minimal pruning will keep the tree healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fraser fir","description":"Abies fraseri, the Fraser fir, is a species of fir native to the Appalachian Mountains of the Southeastern United States.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North Carolina","Tennessee","Virginia"],"other_name":["Fraser fir"],"pest_susceptibility":["Balsam woolly adelgid"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Abies fraseri"],"soil":["Acidic","Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be careful not to remove too much of the plant at once, as ferns can be sensitive to extensive cutting. If you notice any dead or discolored parts on your lichen, gently trim them away using clean scissors to prevent any potential spread of decay. Since lichens grow slowly, be careful not to damage any healthy parts when removing dead material. Avoid using any chemical treatments near Cladonia squamosa, as lichens are highly sensitive to pollutants and contaminants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dragon Horn","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Northern Hemisphere"],"other_name":["Dragon Horn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cladonia squamosa"],"soil":["Rocky","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the hot summer months, you might need to water it once or twice a week, whereas in cooler months, watering can be reduced. Mulching helps retain soil moisture and keeps roots cool. It's best planted under high-canopy trees or in a spot where it receives filtered light. If grown in full sun, ensure the soil remains consistently moist to prevent dehydration and stress, which can impact its health and blooming capacity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron prinophyllum is best done immediately after flowering in late spring to early summer. This timing prevents the removal of next year's flower buds that develop soon after blooming. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased wood, and trim back any unruly growth to maintain the plant's shape and size. Thinning out some inner branches can help improve air circulation and light penetration within the plant. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can reduce the following year’s flowers. Light, regular pruning encourages a healthy structure and more abundant blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"early azalea","description":"Rhododendron prinophyllum, the early azalea, is a rhododendron species native to the eastern and southern United States. The best time to prune this tree is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent infection. Be cautious to use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, and avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree and reduce blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"South African Coral Tree","description":"Erythrina caffra, the coast coral tree or African coral tree, is a tree native to southeastern Africa, which is often cultivated and has introduced populations in India. It prefers its soil to be on the drier side, so it is important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot as lavender does not thrive in wet conditions. When planted in its optimal lighting conditions, English lavender will produce its best blooms and maintain a compact and tidy shape. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent the plants from becoming scorched. Ensure its placement has good air circulation and is not overshadowed by other plants. If growing indoors, choose a south-facing window that receives plenty of sunlight for successful growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lavandula angustifolia is essential to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in the late summer after the plant has finished blooming. Remove about one-third of the plant's height, making sure not to cut into the woody parts, as this can hinder new growth. Trim spent flower stalks and tidy the foliage by cutting back overgrown stems. In early spring, you can lightly prune again if necessary to maintain a healthy structure. Regular pruning also helps in promoting more prolific blooms in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Lavender","description":"Lavandula angustifolia (lavender most commonly true lavender or English lavender, though not native to England; also garden lavender, common lavender, narrow-leaved lavender), formerly L. officinalis, is a flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae, native to the Mediterranean (Spain, France, Italy, Croatia etc.).","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Common Lavender"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Lavandula angustifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14484,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia bicolor, also known as snow-on-the-prairie, prefers environments that mimic its native habitat. This plant is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering once established. It is best to water Euphorbia bicolor sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In general, watering every two to three weeks during the growing season should suffice, and even less frequently during dormant periods. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the plant is not sitting in waterlogged soil. Use well-draining soil to enhance proper drainage and maintain plant health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia bicolor thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure to sunlight encourages the vibrant colors and robust growth that are typical of healthy plants. However, if you live in an area with intense midday sun, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight might lead to less vibrant foliage and reduced flowering. If growing indoors, place this plant near a south or west-facing window for the best light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia bicolor is not typically necessary, but it can be done to control size and shape or to remove any dead or damaged stems. Deadheading is recommended, which involves removing spent flowers to encourage additional blooming and to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. In late fall or early winter, cut back the entire plant to about two inches above the ground once the foliage has died back and turned brown. This helps to tidy the plant for the winter months and encourages robust growth the following spring. It can tolerate direct sunlight, especially in temperate climates, but in hotter regions, the plant benefits from some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch. Ideally, position the plant where it can receive morning sun and filtered light during the hottest part of the day. If grown indoors, placing it near an east or north-facing window would allow optimal light exposure. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light is crucial for promoting vibrant blooms and robust growth, but protect it from excessive direct midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Sprekelia formosissima involves removing spent flowers and any yellow or dying foliage. After the plant has finished blooming, cut back the flower stalk close to the base to conserve the plant’s energy. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Typically, watering every 1-2 weeks is sufficient, but this can vary depending on climate and soil conditions. During hotter months, you might need to water more frequently. Ensure that the soil has good drainage to keep the roots healthy. In winter, reduce watering as the plant requires less moisture during its dormant period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Boxwood plants thrive in partial to full sun, making them quite versatile for garden placement. Ideally, Buxus sempervirens should receive about 3-6 hours of sunlight per day. They can adapt to full sun, provided they have adequate moisture, but they do best in partial shade where they are shielded from harsh afternoon sunlight. Excessive direct sunlight can cause leaf scorch, so if planted in full sun, consider a location that offers some cover or provide afternoon shade to protect the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Buxus sempervirens should be done in late spring and throughout the summer to maintain its shape and size. Use sharp pruners to remove any dead or diseased branches as they appear. For decorative shaping, lightly trim the outer foliage to encourage a compact form, but avoid cutting into noticeably bare or woody areas, as boxwoods are slow to regenerate new growth. Pruning also aids in airflow and reduces the risk of disease. Conduct a heavier prune every few years to encourage denser growth and overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common box","description":"Buxus sempervirens, the common box, European box, or boxwood, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Buxus, native to western and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia, from southern England south to northern Morocco, and east through the northern Mediterranean region to Turkey. Buxus colchica of western Caucasus and B. hyrcana of northern Iran and eastern Caucasus are commonly treated as synonyms of B. sempervirens.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western Europe","Southern Europe","Northern Africa","Southwest Asia"],"other_name":["common box"],"pest_susceptibility":["Boxwood blight","Boxwood leafminer","Boxwood mite"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Buxus sempervirens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Clay","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In any case, aim to replicate the dappled light conditions found in its natural habitat, and avoid dark or excessively shady locations that might limit its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Asplenium polyodon is fairly straightforward and usually involves removing old, damaged, or dead fronds to encourage new growth and maintain its appearance. It's best to prune at the base of the frond using a clean, sharp pair of scissors or pruning shears to prevent disease. Avoid cutting healthy fronds in the center of the plant, as this can lead to stress. Pruning should be done as needed and when you notice the fronds turning yellow or brown, ensuring the crown of the plant is not disturbed during the process."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mare's Tail Fern","description":"Asplenium polyodon, commonly known as sickle spleenwort, is a species of fern in the family Aspleniaceae. Instead, provide diffused light or indirect sunlight to mimic its natural habitat, which supports healthy mycelium development and sporocarp formation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Gymnopus dryophilus does not require traditional pruning. As a fungus, its lifecycle involves the natural decay and regrowth of fruiting bodies. If cultivating in a controlled environment, periodically remove any decayed or over-mature mushroom caps to maintain overall cleanliness and prevent potential mold growth. However, leave healthy mycelial networks intact, as they are vital for the continuous development of new fruiting bodies and for performing their ecological role within their environment."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Oak-loving Gymnopus","description":"Gymnopus dryophilus is a mushroom commonly found in temperate woodlands of Europe and North America. It is generally saprophytic, but occasionally also attacks living wood. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15478,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gaillardia aestivalis, commonly known as annual blanket flower, prefers well-drained soil and is somewhat drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant thoroughly when the soil feels dry to the touch, generally every 7-10 days, especially during dry spells. Avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. The plant is well adapted to dry conditions and can tolerate short periods of drought, but regular watering will promote more vibrant blooms. Ensure good drainage and limit watering during cooler months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gaillardia aestivalis thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sun each day for optimal blooming. Planting in a location that receives abundant sunshine will ensure the plant develops its full coloration and stays healthy. While it can tolerate some partial shade, insufficient light will result in fewer blooms and a leggy appearance. In regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching, but overall, full sun is ideal for this resilient flowering species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gaillardia aestivalis involves deadheading spent blooms to encourage continuous flowering and to tidy up the plant. Regularly remove the wilted flowers by cutting them back to a leaf node or a lateral bud. This not only promotes more blooms but also prevents the plant from focusing its energy on seed production. In late fall or early spring, you can cut the plant back by about one-third to maintain its shape and vigor, removing any dead or damaged stems to encourage fresh growth in the new season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lanceleaf blanketflower","description":"Gaillardia aestivalis is a species of flowering plant in the aster family known by the common name lanceleaf blanketflower. It is native to the south-central and southern United States from Texas east to Florida and north to the Carolinas, Arkansas, and Kansas. There are also reports of historical (now extirpated) populations in Missouri and introduced populations in Nebraska. It is also cultivated as an ornamental plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Lanceleaf blanketflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Gaillardia aestivalis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15682,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron hirsutum requires moderate watering. The soil should always be kept moist but not waterlogged. During dry periods or particularly hot weather, you may need to water more frequently. It’s best to water at the base of the plant early in the morning or late afternoon to minimize water evaporation. Be cautious with the water quality; rainwater is ideal as hard tap water can be too alkaline, which may stress the plant. In winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters its dormant phase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron hirsutum prefers partial shade; however, it can tolerate some sunlight. Ideally, the plant should receive morning sun followed by afternoon shade. Too much direct sun can lead to leaf scorch, especially in hotter climates. A spot with dappled sunlight under the canopy of larger trees is typically perfect. If planted in an area with strong afternoon sun, ensure there is some shelter to protect it. Additionally, consider wind protection as Rhododendrons can be sensitive to strong winds that dry out their foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Rhododendron hirsutum is minimal but important for maintaining shape and removing any dead or diseased wood. Ideally, pruning should be done immediately after flowering, around late spring or early summer. This timing ensures that you don't cut off next year's flower buds. Focus on removing dead or unhealthy branches and shaping the plant to encourage open, airy growth, which helps reduce pests and disease. Avoid heavy pruning as Rhododendrons do not respond well to it and it may stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairy Alpenrose","description":"Rhododendron hirsutum, the hairy alpenrose is one of the species of Rhododendron native to the mountains of Europe. It occurs in the Eastern Alps, and has been naturalised in parts of the Carpathians. It grows on carbonate-rich soils, whereas its close relative R. ferrugineum grows on acid soils; where the two occur together, they frequently produce the hybrid Rhododendron × intermedium.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Alps","Europe"],"other_name":["Hairy Alpenrose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron hirsutum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Monitor your indoor humidity and consider using a humidity tray if necessary, ensuring the plant doesn’t sit directly in water to prevent sogginess."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pilophorus acicularis thrives in indirect light conditions, as it’s adapted to grow in partial sunlight environments like shaded forests or rock surfaces. Ensure it is not placed near direct windows with harsh midday sun, as this can lead to desiccation. If indoors, a north-facing window or an area away from intense artificial lighting is ideal to mimic its natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pilophorus acicularis is minimal as it’s more about maintaining its shape and removing any damaged parts rather than encouraging growth like with other plants. Carefully snip away any dead or discolored sections with sterilized scissors to prevent infection. As lichens grow slowly, be gentle to avoid damaging healthy parts. Ensure that any pruning done doesn’t disturb its attachment to any substrate it grows on, like rocks or branches, to prevent uprooting the entire lichen body."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Devil's matchstick","description":"Pilophorus acicularis, commonly known as the nail lichen or the devil's matchstick, is a species of lichen in the Cladoniaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Devil's matchstick"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal issues","Moss and Algae growth"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pilophorus acicularis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14486,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hypsizygus ulmarius, commonly known as the elm oyster mushroom, requires a carefully balanced watering regimen for optimal growth. During the colonization phase, maintain a high humidity environment to prevent the substrate from drying out, which can involve misting the substrate surface lightly. Once fruiting begins, continue to keep the environment humid—around 85-95% relative humidity is ideal—to support proper mushroom development. Be cautious not to overwater as excessive moisture can lead to contamination, particularly by green molds. Ensure good air circulation to help manage moisture levels and avoid standing water in the growing area."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypsizygus ulmarius does not require direct sunlight as part of its growing conditions. Instead, they thrive in indirect light or under artificial lighting setups. Bright, indirect light levels are sufficient because mushrooms do not photosynthesize, but light can aid in orientation and proper development of fruiting bodies. Artificial lights that emit in the blue to natural daylight spectrum can simulate the necessary conditions effectively if grown indoors. Ensure that light exposure is consistent to support uniform mushroom growth, typically in durations similar to natural light cycles of about 12 hours on and 12 hours off."},{"type":"pruning","description":"While traditional pruning is not applied to mushrooms, maintaining the growing environment is crucial for Hypsizygus ulmarius. Regularly inspect the mycelium and emerging mushrooms to remove any fruits that show signs of contamination, such as mold growth or decay, which could spread to healthy specimens. Ensure to harvest mature mushrooms promptly, as this encourages successive fruiting waves. Cleanliness of the growing environment and substrate maintenance is key, removing spent or deteriorated mushrooms to support the health of new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Elm Mushroom","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Europe"],"other_name":["Elm Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Hypsizygus ulmarius"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14786,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stachys floridana, commonly known as Florida Betony or Rattlesnake Weed, requires moderate watering. It thrives in well-drained soil, so it's important to avoid water logging which can lead to root rot. During the growing season, you should water the plant when the top 1-2 inches of soil feel dry. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down. Ensure that the pot or planting area has good drainage to prevent excess moisture accumulation. This plant is somewhat drought-tolerant, but regular watering helps maintain its vibrant appearance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stachys floridana grows best in full sun to partial shade. It adapts well to different light conditions but performing optimally when it receives about 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, partial shade during the afternoon can protect the plant from intense heat and prevent leaf scorch. Alternatively, in cooler regions, full sun will help promote healthier growth and more prolific flowering. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive adequate sunlight. Adjust the position as necessary to prevent leggy growth and ensure vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stachys floridana involves removing spent flower stalks and dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth and flowering. Too much direct sunlight can dry out the fungus and hinder its growth; therefore, it's essential to protect it from direct, harsh sunlight. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14386,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Peltigera britannica, like many lichens, generally obtains most of its moisture from the environment, such as rain, mist, or dew, and does not require regular watering like typical house plants. However, if it's kept indoors or in an artificially dry environment, lightly mist the lichen with water using a spray bottle every few days. Avoid over-watering, as lichens are adapted to thrive in environments with variable moisture levels; excessive moisture can be detrimental. Ensure they have good air circulation to provide a balance of moisture and proper drying intervals."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Peltigera britannica prefers environments with indirect or dappled sunlight, similar to its natural woodland or mountainous habitats. Direct sunlight, especially intense afternoon sun, can be too harsh and may dry out the lichen excessively. If kept indoors, place the lichen where it can receive filtered light, such as near a north-facing window or under partial shade in a greenhouse. In natural habitats, they are often found in partially shaded areas which provide a balance of light and humidity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Typically, lichens such as Peltigera britannica do not require pruning as conventional plants do. However, regular grooming can be beneficial to maintain their appearance and health. Remove any debris like fallen leaves or twigs from the colony to keep it clean. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15387,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sida cordifolia prefers moderate watering. It thrives in well-drained soil, and it is crucial to water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so make sure the pot has good drainage. During the growing season, keep the soil consistently moist, but reduce irrigation in the winter months when the plant’s growth slows down. It is better to underwater than overwater as Sida cordifolia is relatively drought-tolerant once established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sida cordifolia thrives in full sun conditions. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to maintain healthy growth and flower production. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive ample light. Inadequate sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. However, in extremely hot climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent the leaves from scorching. Consistent exposure to bright light will yield the best results for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sida cordifolia is essential to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. It should be pruned in early spring, just before the growing season begins. Trim back any dead, diseased, or damaged branches using clean, sharp pruning shears. Lightly shape the plant by cutting back overgrown branches to encourage bushier growth. Regular pruning also helps to control its size and encourages the production of more flowers on healthy, new growth. Always sterilize tools before use to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"flannel weed","description":"Sida cordifolia ('ilima, flannel weed, bala, country mallow or heart-leaf sida) is a perennial subshrub of the mallow family Malvaceae native to India. It has naturalized throughout the world, and is considered an invasive weed in Africa, Australia, the southern United States, Hawaiian Islands, New Guinea, and French Polynesia. The specific name, cordifolia, refers to the heart-shaped leaf.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Sri Lanka","Southern Africa","Australia"],"other_name":["flannel weed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Sida cordifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If growing outdoors, positioning it under a tree canopy or shaded area is ideal. Ensuring it receives adequate but not excessive light will help maintain its vibrant colors and growth. Be attentive to the light conditions to avoid any bleaching or drying effects."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Heterodermia leucomelos is not typically necessary as it's a lichen, but some light maintenance might be required to keep it healthy and aesthetically pleasing. If there are any dead or discolored sections of the lichen, you can gently remove them with tweezers or trim them with small scissors. Take care not to damage the healthy parts. Additionally, if the lichen is growing on a surface where it's not desired, careful removal and relocation to a suitable substrate are recommended. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14590,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phaseolus vulgaris, commonly known as the common bean, prefers consistent moisture. Water it thoroughly to maintain evenly moist soil, especially during flowering and pod development. However, avoid waterlogging, as beans do not like soggy conditions. A general rule is to water once a week, adjusting based on rainfall and temperature. Let the top inch of soil dry out before watering again. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool. It's important to water at the base of the plant to minimize wetting the foliage, which can encourage fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phaseolus vulgaris thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. This optimizes blooming and pod production. Ensure they are planted in a location where they will not be shaded by taller plants or structures, as adequate sunlight is crucial for vigorous growth. If growing in a particularly hot climate, some afternoon shade can help prevent stress but ensure that the plants aren't deprived of their daily sunlight requirements. The more consistent the access to sunlight, the better your beans will perform throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Phaseolus vulgaris is mostly minimal and involves removing damaged or diseased stems and leaves to encourage healthy growth. As with many bush beans, they generally do not require extensive pruning. However, regularly check for any twisted parts that might invite pests or diseases and remove them promptly. Pinching the growing tips of the plant can promote bushy growth and more pods if you notice leggy growth. Pruning is also essential at the end of the growing season to clear away dead or dying plant matter and help prevent pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Bean","description":"Phaseolus vulgaris, the common bean (also known as the string bean, field bean, flageolet bean, French bean, garden bean, green bean, haricot bean, pop bean, snap bean, or snap), is a herbaceous annual plant grown worldwide for its edible dry seed (known as just \"beans\") or unripe fruit (green beans). Raw or undercooked beans contain a toxic protein called phytohaemagglutinin. Its leaf is also occasionally used as a vegetable and the straw as fodder. Its botanical...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Common Bean"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Bean beetles","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Phaseolus vulgaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15186,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cycas revoluta, commonly known as the sago palm, requires careful watering to avoid root rot. Water this plant when the topsoil feels dry to the touch, approximately every one to two weeks depending on the climate and time of year. It's important to water deeply and allow the excess moisture to drain out of the pot. Reduce watering frequency in winter as the plant's growth slows down. Overwatering is a common issue, so ensure that the plant's soil is well-draining and never let it sit in standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cycas revoluta thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sun. It prefers a location that receives filtered sunlight for several hours a day. If grown indoors, a spot near an east or west-facing window where it can receive bright, indirect light will be ideal. Too much direct sunlight can cause leaf burn, while insufficient light may lead to poor growth. Adjust the plant's location indoors to ensure it receives adequate light, especially during winter when natural sunlight is limited."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cycas revoluta involves removing yellow or dead fronds at the base of the plant to maintain its aesthetic and health. This should be done at least once a year, during its non-growing season, preferably in late winter. Avoid over-pruning and never remove more than one-third of the foliage at one time. The removal of healthy fronds should be avoided as they are necessary for photosynthesis and overall plant health. Also, be cautious of the sharp spines present at the base of the leaf petioles while pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sago cycad","description":"Cycas revoluta (Sotetsu , sago palm, king sago, sago cycad, Japanese sago palm), is a species of gymnosperm in the family Cycadaceae, native to southern Japan including the Ryukyu Islands. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14787,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia misella, commonly known as Blue Sage, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It is important to allow the topsoil to dry out between watering sessions, as this plant does not thrive in consistently wet soil. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogging. During the growing season, watering once every week or two is generally sufficient, depending on the climate and soil conditions. In the winter, water less frequently, allowing the soil to remain slightly drier."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia misella thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. It requires at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat and prevent leaf burn. However, too much shade may result in fewer flowers and leggy growth. Therefore, it is important to observe how the plant responds to its current light conditions and adjust its position accordingly to ensure vibrant blooms and healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia misella can help promote bushier growth and maintain the plant's shape. It is best to prune this plant in the spring, after the last frost, as well as during the growing season to remove spent blooms and encourage new growth. Trim back any dead or damaged stems and remove spent flower spikes to prevent leggy growth and promote better blooming. Regular light pruning can keep the plant healthy and vigorous, while more substantial cutting back can be done to control size and shape as needed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"River sage","description":"Salvia misella, tropical sage, is an annual herb growing throughout tropical America, often found in semi-arid regions on disturbed bushy ground, from sea level to 2,200 metres (7,200 ft). It is similar, and perhaps closely related to, Salvia occidentalis, with a longer calyx (7 millimetres (0.28 in)) and a 5 millimetres (0.20 in) blue flower.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Florida","West Indies","Central America"],"other_name":["River sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia misella"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy Soil"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid over-watering or allowing water to pool, as lichens are sensitive to extended water exposure, which may lead to decay. If kept indoors, placing it near a humidifier or in a bathroom can help maintain the necessary moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Graphis scripta thrives in partial to full shade, as direct sunlight can be too harsh and drying. It naturally occurs on tree bark in forested areas where it is protected from intense sun exposure. If growing indoors, place it in a bright room but away from direct sunrays, possibly near a north-facing window or beneath filtered light. When growing outdoors, ensure it is in a shaded spot, particularly if planting on surfaces that may increase exposure to direct sunlight, to protect this lichen’s preference for more subdued lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Graphis scripta is not typically necessary, as lichens grow slowly and do not have leaves or stems like traditional plants. However, if you notice any dead or decayed sections due to poor conditions, carefully trim away the affected parts using small, sterilized scissors. It's essential to handle lichens delicately and avoid removing too much material at once. Regularly check for signs of environmental stress that may necessitate intervention, such as significant discoloration or detachment from the substrate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Script Lichen","description":"Graphis scripta is a crustose lichen in the Graphidaceae family. It is commonly called script lichen, secret writing lichen, or similar names, because its growth pattern makes it looks like writing. Stigmidium microspilum and Arthonia graphidicola are associated lichenicolous fungi. It is variable with either curved or stellate apothecia. The margins are carbonaceous and raised, without furrows. Mature spores are without color, but become brown with age.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Common Script Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Graphis scripta"],"soil":["Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14788,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calycanthus floridus, also known as Carolina Allspice, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. It benefits from regular watering, especially during dry spells, to maintain soil moisture. However, be cautious of overwatering as it can lead to root rot. Well-draining soil helps prevent waterlogging. During its dormancy in winter, water should be reduced. Mulching can help retain moisture and maintain even soil conditions. In general, aim to water deeply once a week, adjusting frequency based on rainfall and temperature, ensuring the soil remains consistently damp but not soggy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calycanthus floridus thrives in a range of sunlight conditions but prefers partial shade to full sun. In areas with intense afternoon heat, providing some light shade will help protect the leaves from scorching. However, in cooler climates, full sun can enhance flowering and growth. An ideal location would receive morning sun with some protective shade during afternoon to prevent heat stress. Ensure the site chosen provides balanced light conditions to support both vigorous growth and prolific blooming, adapting exposure based on regional climate variations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calycanthus floridus is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased wood to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Additionally, pruning for shape and size control can be done, focusing on thinning out dense areas to allow light and air to penetrate the plant. If necessary, rejuvenation pruning can be carried out by cutting back around one-third of the oldest stems to the ground every 3-4 years, which encourages new growth and maintains a tidy appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina sweetshrub","description":"Calycanthus (sweetshrub) is a genus of flowering plants in the family Calycanthaceae, endemic to North America. During spring and summer, the plant may require more frequent watering as it is actively growing, but reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Always check the top inch of soil, and water only when it begins to feel dry to avoid overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bistorta officinalis thrives best in partial to full sunlight. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily, which can be full morning sun or dappled sunlight throughout the day. In hotter climates, partial shade is beneficial as it prevents the leaves from scorching under intense afternoon sunlight. However, in cooler climates, full sun can enhance flowering. Ensuring the right balance of sunlight helps the plant develop strong stems and vibrant flowers, contributing to its overall health and appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bistorta officinalis involves removing spent flower stalks to encourage tidy growth and sometimes a second bloom in the season. After flowering, trim back the flower stalks at the base of the plant to prevent seeding and to promote a bushier appearance. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant healthy. In early spring, cut back any dead growth to make way for new shoots. Regular pruning helps maintain the plant’s shape and encourages more vigorous blooms for the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common bistort","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["common bistort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Bistorta officinalis"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Excessive direct sunlight can lead to scorched leaves, so ensure some level of shade throughout the day, particularly in warmer regions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Viola reichenbachiana is generally minimal and should be done to maintain the plant's shape and health. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, it can be lightly cut back in late autumn or early spring to rejuvenate growth. Pruning also helps in managing the plant’s size and can prevent it from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Helmet skullcap","description":"Scutellaria integrifolia, commonly called helmet flower or helmet skullcap, is a flowering plant in the mint family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14284,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drimia maritima, often known as Sea Squill, is a drought-tolerant plant and requires minimal watering. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to bulb rot. In the active growing season (spring and autumn), water occasionally to keep the plant hydrated. During its dormant period in the summer, reduce watering significantly or stop altogether, as the plant is adapted to endure dry spells in its natural habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drimia maritima thrives in full sun to partial shade. For best growth and flowering, provide plenty of bright, direct sunlight. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of full sunlight daily. In areas with very hot summers, some afternoon shade might protect the plant from heat stress. When grown indoors, position the plant near a south or west-facing window to maximize light exposure. Keep in mind that insufficient sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and weaker growth. Adjust exposure according to the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"This plant generally requires little pruning. Remove any yellow or dead leaves to maintain appearance and health, especially at the end of the growing season in autumn. If the flower stalks become unsightly after blooming, they can also be cut back. Be cautious when handling the plant, as Drimia maritima can be toxic and may irritate the skin. Use gloves when necessary, and ensure tools are clean to prevent disease spread. Regular maintenance through removing old growth can help promote healthy new development each growing cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sea squill","description":"Drimia maritima (syn. Urginea maritima) is a species of flowering plant in the family Asparagaceae, subfamily Scilloideae (formerly the family Hyacinthaceae). This species is known by several common names, including squill, sea squill, sea onion, and maritime squill. It may also be called red squill, particularly a form which produces red-tinged flowers instead of white. It is native to southern Europe, western Asia, and northern Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","North Africa"],"other_name":["sea squill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Drimia maritima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regularly pinch out the growing tips during the early growth stage to promote lateral branching. Deadhead spent flowers throughout the blooming season to encourage new blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. At the end of the growing season, or if the plant outgrows its space, you can perform a more extensive cut back to manage its size and shape. Pruning also helps in reducing the spread of any diseased or damaged parts, enhancing overall plant health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Black-eyed Susan vine","description":"Thunbergia alata, commonly called Black-eyed Susan vine, is a herbaceous perennial climbing plant species in the Acanthaceae family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14989,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Heuchera richardsonii, commonly known as Richardson's alumroot, prefers well-drained soil and does not require excessive watering. It is quite drought-tolerant once established, making it suitable for xeriscaping. Water the plant regularly during the first growing season to establish a deep root system, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it is important to ensure good drainage. During prolonged dry spells, occasional watering may be beneficial, but the plant can generally withstand typical dry periods without additional water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Richardson's alumroot thrives in partial shade to full sun conditions; however, in hotter climates, it prefers some afternoon shade to prevent the foliage from scorching. In cooler climates, it can handle more direct sunlight throughout the day. Ideally, provide dappled sunlight or light morning sun with afternoon shade to mimic its natural woodland habitat. Too much shade can result in reduced flowering and less vibrant foliage, so it is crucial to adjust the light conditions based on your regional climate to optimize growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Heuchera richardsonii can help maintain its appearance and promote healthy growth. Remove any spent flower stalks after blooming to prevent seed production and encourage more blooms. In early spring, cut back any old, dead, or damaged leaves to make way for new growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or has a lot of woody stems at the base, consider dividing the plant every 3-4 years. This will rejuvenate the plant and encourage more vigorous leaf production. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread during pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prairie alumroot","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["prairie alumroot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Heuchera richardsonii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14789,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ficus elastica, commonly known as the rubber plant, prefers consistent moisture but does not tolerate standing water well. Water the plant when the top inch of soil becomes dry to the touch. Make sure to use a pot with drainage holes to prevent water accumulation in the container, which can lead to root rot. Reduce the frequency of watering in the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Additionally, it can benefit from occasional misting to increase humidity, especially in dry indoor environments."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus elastica thrives in bright, indirect light. Direct sunlight can cause leaf scorch, while too little light can lead to leggy growth. Ideal conditions include placing the plant near an east or north-facing window where it can receive plenty of light without being exposed to harsh rays. If grown in a particularly shaded area, it may adapt over time but its growth rate will likely slow. Rotating the plant periodically can ensure even light exposure and balanced growth. Supplement with artificial light if necessary in low-light situations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus elastica is essential to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. You can prune the plant at any time of the year; however, it's best done in the spring or early summer. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to cut back any leggy or overgrown branches just above a node or leaf. Remove any dead or damaged leaves as needed. Wear gloves when pruning as the sap can be irritating to the skin. Pruning also helps in controlling the plant's height and promotes a healthier appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"rubber plant","description":"Ficus elastica, the rubber fig, rubber bush, rubber tree, rubber plant, or Indian rubber bush, Indian rubber tree, is a species of plant in the fig genus, native to east India, Nepal, Bhutan, Burma, China (Yunnan), Malaysia, and Indonesia. It has become naturalized in Sri Lanka, the West Indies, and the US State of Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeast Asia","India"],"other_name":["rubber plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Air Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ficus elastica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15086,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vitis aestivalis, commonly known as the summer grape, prefers consistent moisture but is fairly drought tolerant once established. During the growing season, the plant should be watered regularly to keep the soil moderately moist, especially during dry periods. It's important to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as overly wet soil conditions can harm the plant. In general, deep watering once a week, allowing the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings, is optimal. Adjust watering based on seasonal rainfall and soil conditions, with less frequent watering needed once the plant is well established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vitis aestivalis thrives in full sun conditions and requires a minimum of 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow healthily and produce fruit. Adequate sunlight exposure ensures the vines develop strong growth and high fruit quality. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight will lead to poor growth, reduced fruiting, and susceptibility to diseases. If planted in a shady location, pruning surrounding vegetation can help increase sunlight exposure. Therefore, selecting a planting site with ample sun is crucial for the successful cultivation of Vitis aestivalis."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vitis aestivalis is crucial for maintaining plant health, vigor, and productivity. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged wood to prevent disease. Additionally, thinning the vines can improve air circulation, reducing disease risk. For training purposes, keep the strongest canes and remove excess growth, focusing on forming a structured framework. Prune to encourage fruiting on 1-year-old wood, known as spurs, by cutting back each one to two or three buds. Summer pruning can also be done to control growth and shape the vine."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"summer grape","description":"Vitis aestivalis, the summer grape, or pigeon grape is a species of grape native to eastern North America from southern Ontario east to Maine, west to Oklahoma, and south to Florida and Texas. It is a vigorous vine, growing to 10 m or more high in trees. The leaves are 7–20 cm long, suborbicular, and usually a little broader than long; they are variable in shape, from unlobed to deeply three- or five-lobed, green above, and densely...","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Dark blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["summer grape"],"pest_susceptibility":["Grape berry moth","Leafhoppers"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vitis aestivalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15188,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Stachys sylvatica, commonly known as hedge woundwort, prefers consistently moist soil but is relatively drought tolerant once established. To maintain optimal growth, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry, ensuring the soil remains slightly damp but not waterlogged. During hot and dry spells, increase the watering frequency to prevent the plant from wilting. It's crucial to avoid allowing the roots to sit in standing water, so ensure proper drainage in the soil. In cooler months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows, but don't let it completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stachys sylvatica thrives best in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. It prefers environments where it receives indirect sunlight for most of the day, or dappled sunlight filtering through other plants or trees. Although it can tolerate full shade, providing some morning or late afternoon sun can enhance flowering. Avoid placing the plant in direct, harsh sunlight for extended periods, as this could stress the plant and lead to wilting or leaf scorch. Finding the right balance of light will ensure vibrant growth and a healthy plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stachys sylvatica involves removing dead or damaged stems and foliage to promote healthy growth and shape the plant. After the flowering period, it's beneficial to cut back the flower spikes to encourage a tidier appearance and prevent self-seeding, which this plant may do prolifically. In early spring, prune any old or dead growth to make way for new shoots. Regular deadheading of blooms can also enhance flowering. Be sure to wear gloves when pruning, as the plant's foliage can have a rank odor when handled. Consistent pruning helps maintain a compact and vigorous growth habit."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"hedge woundwort","description":"Stachys sylvatica, commonly known as hedge woundwort, whitespot, or sometimes as hedge nettle, is a perennial herb growing to 80 cm tall in woodland and unmanaged grassland. In temperate zones of the northern hemisphere it flowers in July and August. The flowers are purple. The leaves, when crushed or bruised, give off an unpleasant fetid smell.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["hedge woundwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Stachys sylvatica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During periods of extended drought, occasional deep watering can support the plant, but care should be taken not to overwater, as it prefers conditions on the drier side. Ensure that the soil dries out between watering sessions to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the plant's root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hippocrepis comosa thrives best in full sun, reflecting its adaptation to open, sunny habitats. Plant it in a location where it will receive ample sunlight, such as a south-facing slope or garden area free from shading by larger plants or structures. While it can tolerate some light shade, significantly reduced sunlight can lead to fewer blooms and a less vigorous plant overall. Ensuring adequate sunlight is key to its successful cultivation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Hippocrepis comosa is generally minimal. Avoid heavy pruning in autumn, as it may affect the plant's ability to withstand winter conditions. Remove any damaged or dead plant material as needed throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"horseshoe vetch","description":"Hippocrepis comosa, the horseshoe vetch) is a species of perennial flowering plant belonging to the genus Hippocrepis in the Fabaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["horseshoe vetch"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Hippocrepis comosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Chalky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
